repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Economic and Financial
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic and Financial
            Management Project in Honduras were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Lessons learned included: 1) Improvements
            toward greater transparency, efficiency and modernization of
            the public sector are gradual processes that require
            important preparatory investments and long-term
            implementation periods, in order to achieve significant
            changes within the context of such an ambitious program; 2)
            The implementation period originally assigned to this
            operation proved unrealistic; 3) An assessment of the
            project's achievements can only be determined once the
            Public Sector Modernization Technical Assistance Credit
            (PRSTAC) has been completed, since implementation of most of
            the reforms are expected to take place under the new
            operation; 4) In the design of future operations it is
            recommended to separate initiatives regarding public sector
            management and civil service reform from those directed at
            the reform of public services and private sector
            participation processes; and 5) An important factor to be
            considered in operations such as the Economic and Financial
            Management Technical Assistance Credit (EFMTAC), that not
            only contemplate the strengthening of key government
            institutions, but also include approval and implementation
            of reforms, is to take into account the political calendar cycles.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Economic and Financial
            Management Project : proposed amendment to the Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This report amends the Development
            Credit Agreement of the Honduras Economic and Financial
            Management Project (Cr. No. 3414- HO.). Although the
            original development objective would remain valid, the
            proposed Amendment as outlined in Section IV of the
            amendment document, would restructure the ongoing operation
            to better align it to the public sector reform priorities
            introduced by the Administration that assumed office in
            January 2002. Namely, a new component, Administrative Reform
            and Public Sector Reengineering (Component E) would be added
            to support a series of comprehensive studies and
            administrative reform strategies which would provide the
            basis for future reengineering of the public sector.
            Additionally, since a comprehensive Inter-American
            Development Bank-sponsored project will support the
            development and implementation of the new Public Procurement
            Law, the limited support that was originally envisioned
            under the Public Procurement Component (original Component
            E) would no longer be necessary. Therefore, this component
            would be dropped and proceeds reallocated to reinforce
            Government efforts in remaining components.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Economic and Financial
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic and Financial Management
            Project in Honduras, will improve the use, and allocation of
            public resources, develop budgetary plans, and evaluation
            capacity in government agencies, and promote institutional
            restructuring within the telecommunications, ports, and
            postal services sectors. The components will: 1) strengthen
            the Secretariat of Finance, and in line Secretariats, in
            support of the integrated financial management system
            (SIAFI), which will operate in budget, treasury, accounting,
            and public credit areas. Legal framework will be enhanced,
            and an organizational restructuring will take place; 2)
            modernize audit institutions, and provide technical
            assistance to the Office of the Comptroller General, through
            institutional strengthening, civil society's
            participation, and comprehensive training programs; 3)
            develop human resources management policies, through
            technical assistance, and training; 4) support the
            development of performance-oriented management, and
            evaluation capacity in the public sector; 5) increase the
            efficiency of public procurement, through technical
            assistance, and training regarding the new public
            procurement information system, and strengthen regulatory,
            and institutional framework; and, 6) consolidate regulatory
            reforms within the telecommunications, ports, and postal
            services, assisting in the privatization process, and
            restructuring strategies.
